content:
John Baez said:

Yes, a simple and beautiful argument called the [[Eckmann-Hilton argument]] shows that if CCC is symmetric monoidal, a monoid in Mon(C)\mathsf{Mon}(C)Mon(C) is the same as a commutative monoid in CCC. So Mon(Mon(C))\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{Mon}(C))Mon(Mon(C)) is the category of commutative monoids in CCC.

The Eckmann-Hilton argument seems to keep popping up! When I have a bit more energy, I'd like to work through it, to understand it - and then aim to understand why Mon(Mon(C))\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{Mon}(C))Mon(Mon(C)) is the category of commutative monoids in CCC.
Eugenia Cheng created a nice picture of the Eckmann-Hilton clock, which summarizes the argument. It's a bit cryptic at first:
2 messages were moved here from #learning: questions > defining an internal category without using pullbacks? by John Baez.

That picture looks cool! I look forward to understanding it.

I will start by thinking about this version, from Wikipedia:

Let XXX be a set equipped with two binary operations, which we will write ∘\circ∘ and ⊗\otimes⊗, and suppose:

  1. ∘\circ∘ and ⊗\otimes⊗ are both unital, meaning that there are identity elements 1∘1_{\circ}1∘​ and 1⊗1_{\otimes}1⊗​ of XXX such that 1∘∘a=a=a∘1∘1_{\circ} \circ a = a = a \circ 1_{\circ}1∘​∘a=a=a∘1∘​ and 1⊗⊗a=a=a⊗1⊗1_{\otimes} \otimes a = a = a \otimes 1_{\otimes}1⊗​⊗a=a=a⊗1⊗​, for all a∈Xa \in Xa∈X.
  2. (a⊗b)∘(c⊗d)=(a∘c)⊗(b∘d)(a \otimes b) \circ (c \otimes d) = (a \circ c) \otimes (b \circ d)(a⊗b)∘(c⊗d)=(a∘c)⊗(b∘d) for all a,b,c,d∈Xa,b,c,d \in Xa,b,c,d∈X.

Then ∘\circ∘ and ⊗\otimes⊗ are the same and in fact commutative and associative.

The proof Wikipedia gives seems good to me! I particularly like the two-dimensional proof, where the article uses the fact that (2) is an "interchange law":
interchange law

The "Eckmann-Hilton clock" above, by Eugenia Cheng, seems very similar to the 2D proof that Wikipedia gives, with the addition of a bunch of ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 symbols. I don't know what the ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 symbols are indicating.

At any rate, I quite like the 2D version (e.g. as pictured in the clock). Intuitively, our identity and interchange rules let us "move two elements around one another" by making use of the 2D space available to us. Our ability to do this shows that both operations are equal and commutative.

Now, let us assume that both operations are associative and unital, so they define monoids on XXX. We would like to show that these two conditions are equivalent:

  1. the interchange law is satisfied
  2. ⊗\otimes⊗ is a monoid homomorphism :(X,∘)×(X,∘)→(X,∘):(X, \circ) \times (X, \circ) \to (X, \circ):(X,∘)×(X,∘)→(X,∘) and ∘\circ∘ is a monoid homomorphism :(X,⊗)×(X,⊗)→(X,⊗):(X, \otimes) \times (X, \otimes) \to (X, \otimes):(X,⊗)×(X,⊗)→(X,⊗)

Let us assume that ⊗:X×X→X\otimes: X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X is a monoid homomorphism when we put a monoid structure on X×XX \times XX×X by using ∘\circ∘ elementwise, and where XXX is a monoid witih multiplication given by ∘\circ∘. Doing this, we get the following multiplication on X×XX \times XX×X, which I will write using juxtaposition: (a,b)(c,d)=(a∘c,b∘d)(a,b)(c,d) = (a \circ c,b \circ d)(a,b)(c,d)=(a∘c,b∘d).

If ⊗:X×X→X\otimes: X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X is a morphism of monoids, then for any a,b,c,d∈Xa,b,c,d \in Xa,b,c,d∈X we must have ⊗((a,b)(c,d))=⊗(a,b)∘⊗(c,d)\otimes((a,b)(c,d)) = \otimes(a,b) \circ \otimes(c,d)⊗((a,b)(c,d))=⊗(a,b)∘⊗(c,d) and so we must have ⊗(a∘c,b∘d)=⊗(a,b)∘⊗(c,d)\otimes(a \circ c, b \circ d)= \otimes(a,b) \circ \otimes(c,d)⊗(a∘c,b∘d)=⊗(a,b)∘⊗(c,d). Using infix notation, we must have (a∘c)⊗(b∘d)=(a⊗b)∘(c⊗d)(a \circ c) \otimes (b \circ d) = (a \otimes b) \circ (c \otimes d)(a∘c)⊗(b∘d)=(a⊗b)∘(c⊗d). So, the interchange law holds if ⊗:X×X→X\otimes:X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X is a monoid homomorphism, where XXX and X×XX \times XX×X have monoid structures induced by ∘\circ∘!

We could also carry out a similar argument to show that the interchange law holds if ∘:X×X→X\circ:X \times X \to X∘:X×X→X is a monoid homomorphism, where XXX and X×XX \times XX×X have monoid structures induced by ⊗\otimes⊗.

If the interchange law holds, and both operations are associative and unital, then is ⊗:X×X→X\otimes: X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X necessarily a morphism of monoids? ⊗\otimes⊗ will preserve composition, because the interchange law holds. It remains to show it preserves the unit. Since by assumption the interchange law holds and both operations are unital, we know by the Eckmann-Hilton argument that the units of the two operations are the same. So, ⊗(1,1)=1⊗1=1\otimes(1, 1) = 1 \otimes 1 = 1⊗(1,1)=1⊗1=1 is indeed the unit of XXX with respect to the multiplication given by ∘\circ∘.

Similarly, if the interchange law holds, and both operations are associative and unital, then ∘:X×X→X\circ: X \times X \to X∘:X×X→X will be a monoid homomorphism (where X×XX \times XX×X and XXX are made into monoids using ⊗\otimes⊗).

I would next like to prove this:

If XXX is a monoid object in the category Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon of monoids, then XXX is a commutative monoid object in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon.

But I will stop here for today!

David Egolf said:

The "Eckmann-Hilton clock" above, by Eugenia Cheng, seems very similar to the 2D proof that Wikipedia gives, with the addition of a bunch of ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 symbols. I don't know what the ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 symbols are indicating.

Yeah, they're confusing. I bet they're saying that something or other doesn't need to be an equation: it can be just an isomorphism, called ℓ\ellℓ. But we can set ℓ=1\ell = 1ℓ=1, or in other words ignore it, and focus on what's left.

Aside on the ℓ,ℓ−1\ell,\ell^{-1}ℓ,ℓ−1 operations.

I think the ℓ,ℓ−1\ell,\ell^{-1}ℓ,ℓ−1 are present to represent the chirality in an operation most of us take for granted as a single operation (where ⋅\cdot⋅ is either composition identifying leftward with upward)
1⋅x→ℓx→ℓx⋅11\cdot x\overset{\ell}{\to}x\overset{\ell}{\to}x\cdot 11⋅x→ℓx→ℓx⋅1
1⋅x←ℓ−1x←ℓ−1x⋅11\cdot x\overset{\ell^{-1}}{\leftarrow}x\overset{\ell^{-1}}{\leftarrow}x\cdot 11⋅x←ℓ−1x←ℓ−1x⋅1

I believe this is done (1) to preserve the egg-shape (she's very artistic! :), (2) to point out that the "leftward" / "upward" movements of xxx mediated by ℓ\ellℓ are exactly balanced in number to the rightward/downward movements accomplished by ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1.

But why would we care about that? This might matter if 111 was not a global identity. This can occur in submonoids determined by idempotents; ee=eee=eee=e acts as an identity for the submonoid SSS of all elements conjugated through it; M≥S={exe; x∈M}M\geq S=\{exe; ~x\in M\}M≥S={exe; x∈M}. So if you wanted to keep track of wether there were any dangling idempotents left over at the end of a transformation, and which side they were on, this kind of bookkeeping would tell you. Something like a subspace where e(x…y)≠(x…y)ee(x\ldots y)\neq (x\ldots y)ee(x…y)=(x…y)e, simplifying x…yx\ldots yx…y requires using eee, so you need to know "where/if leftovers end up".

The only problem with this theory is of course that we have a cancellation of 1 at the top and bottom of the clock, but no ℓ\ellℓ's appear/disappear there, so... perhaps this points toward a slight generalization where 111 is an identity for the vertical operation, but merely an idempotent for the horizontal operation, and α,β\alpha,\betaα,β are implicitly idempotent-conjugated. shrug

Is anyone aware of circumstance in homotopy where this actually occurs?

The first time I saw Eugenia's diagram was in this paper (page 11), with Michael Makkai, where they used it on a particular example of Penon's 3-categories to show that Penon's definition could not recover all weak categories. There, the diagram does not have ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 (but it technically should). In particular, the arrows ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 can be helpful to clarify calculations in a situation where you are trying to lift some property from a strict context to a weak context in order to show that a certain monoidal category is not braided but symmetric (which is what they were doing).

@Eric M Downes wrote:

perhaps this points toward a slight generalization where 1 is an identity for the vertical operation, but merely an idempotent for the horizontal operation...

You're reminding me of this:

In homotopy theory we get a bicategory from any space XXX, called its fundamental bigroupoid, which has

  • points of XXX as objects,
  • paths in XXX as morphisms,
  • homotopy classes of 'paths-of-paths' (continuous 1-parameter families of paths with fixed endpoints) as 2-morphisms.

Every point xxx has an 'identity' path 1x1_x1x​, the constant map [0,1]→X[0,1] \to X[0,1]→X taking xxx as its value. This in turn has an 'identity' path-of-paths 11x1_{1_x}11x​​, the constant map [0,1]2→X[0,1]^2 \to X[0,1]2→X taking xxx as its value.

11x1_{1_x}11x​​ is truly the identity for the vertical composition of 2-morphisms, but not for the horizontal composition. For horizontal composition, say ⊗\otimes⊗, we instead have a 2-isomorphism

ℓx:1x∘f→f\ell_x : 1_x \circ f \to fℓx​:1x​∘f→f

such that

ℓx(11x∘α)ℓx−1=α \ell_x (1_{1_x} \circ \alpha) \ell_x^{-1} = \alpha ℓx​(11x​​∘α)ℓx−1​=α

for any 1-morphism f:y→xf: y \to xf:y→x and 2-morphism α:f⇒f\alpha: f \Rightarrow fα:f⇒f.

(Here as people often do I'm using the same symbol, in this case ∘\circ∘, for composition of 1-morphisms and horizontal composition of 2-morphisms. I'm denoting vertical composition of 2-morphisms simply by setting the symbols next to each other.)

In fact this is how it works for a typical bicategory.

Maybe this is what Eugenia is talking about? I'm still confused by the use of ℓ\ellℓ in her picture.

Thanks! This is very promising; biking to work is homotopy equivalent to biking to work and then catching my breath for a few minutes, but if I explore with you adjusting the path I take α:f→f\alpha:f\to fα:f→f, it does not make sense to distract our discussion of paths with such details about me pausing for breath or not at the endpoint. Of course in my head, I know that certain paths entail more exhaustion, so internally I keep track of this when actually planning how much time it will take, after we have finished our conversation. Or something.

I'm a little confused by (co)domains though, in your second equation.

Let s:=ℓx(11x∘α)ℓx−1s:= \ell_x(1_{1_x}\circ\alpha)\ell_x^{-1}s:=ℓx​(11x​​∘α)ℓx−1​. Then dom(s)=cod(s)=fdom(s)=cod(s)=fdom(s)=cod(s)=f, but cod(f)=y,dom(f)=xcod(f)=y, dom(f)=xcod(f)=y,dom(f)=x. Maybe you are using an implicit 1f∼f1_f\sim f1f​∼f, but you said ===...
Or maybe there's just a missing fff, and you mean ℓx(11x∘α)ℓx−1f=f\ell_x(1_{1_x}\circ \alpha)\ell_x^{-1}f=fℓx​(11x​​∘α)ℓx−1​f=f?
I meant =α = \alpha=α.
ahhhhhh hmmm ok great I think that all fits then. Why α\alphaα seems to leave fff alone was going to be my next question :)

Eric M Downes said:

Aside on the ℓ,ℓ−1\ell,\ell^{-1}ℓ,ℓ−1 operations.

I think the ℓ,ℓ−1\ell,\ell^{-1}ℓ,ℓ−1 are present to represent the chirality in an operation most of us take for granted as a single operation (where ⋅\cdot⋅ is either composition identifying leftward with upward)
1⋅x→ℓx→ℓx⋅11\cdot x\overset{\ell}{\to}x\overset{\ell}{\to}x\cdot 11⋅x→ℓx→ℓx⋅1
1⋅x←ℓ−1x←ℓ−1x⋅11\cdot x\overset{\ell^{-1}}{\leftarrow}x\overset{\ell^{-1}}{\leftarrow}x\cdot 11⋅x←ℓ−1x←ℓ−1x⋅1

Okay, assuming I understand what's going on, this is not what ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 means. Instead ℓ−1\ell^{-1}ℓ−1 is the inverse of ℓ\ellℓ, and we have iso-2-morphisms

1∘f→ℓf→ℓ−11∘f1 \circ f\overset{\ell}{\to}f \overset{\ell^{-1}}{\to} 1 \circ f 1∘f→ℓf→ℓ−11∘f
f∘1→rf→r−1f∘1f \circ 1 \overset{r}{\rightarrow} f \overset{r^{-1}}{\rightarrow}f \circ 1f∘1→rf→r−1f∘1
it seems to me ℓ\ellℓ is the left unitor of the ambient bicategory, which pops up when α\alphaα and β\betaβ are paired with an identity cell
which is maybe what John got at anyway
If ℓ\ellℓ is the left unitor, surely we’d also need the right unitor to show up for the proof to go through? (We certainly cancel units on the right in the picture)
Yes, that's one of the reasons I'm confused by the use of ℓ\ellℓ in Cheng's diagram.
I think all the 1-morphisms in this diagram are identities, and the left and right unitor coincide on identities.

By definition, the left and right unitors are the same up to commutativity (due to the braiding; i.e. ℓ∘B=r\ell \circ B = rℓ∘B=r). Since the Eckmann-Hilton argument is about showing that something is commutative, I would imagine that Eugenia wanted to remove any relation that was already commutative to only focus on the relations that are not commutative "for free".
Eugenia's version of the Eckmann-Hilton argument is written for endomorphisms of the identity 1-cell in a bicategory, so there is no braiding.

@Mike Shulman Sorry for the confusion, I meant to take the 2-cell BfB_{f}Bf​ defined by the following composite, which gives a formal commutation on every 1-cell f:A→Af:A \to Af:A→A:

ℓf−1∘2rf:f∘1idA⇒idA∘1f\ell^{-1}_{f} \circ_2 r_{f}:f \circ_1 \mathsf{id}_A \Rightarrow \mathsf{id}_A \circ_1 f ℓf−1​∘2​rf​:f∘1​idA​⇒idA​∘1​f,

Also, regarding the fact that left and right unitors coincide on identities, how do we show that the arrow

BidA:idA∘1idA⇒idA∘1idAB_{\mathsf{id}_A}:\mathsf{id}_A \circ_1 \mathsf{id}_A \Rightarrow \mathsf{id}_A \circ_1 \mathsf{id}_ABidA​​:idA​∘1​idA​⇒idA​∘1​idA​

is an identity 2-cell in a bicategory? (or do you mean that they coincide in a different way?)
Here's the proof: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/monoidal+category#kel2

Nathan Corbyn said:

If ℓ\ellℓ is the left unitor, surely we’d also need the right unitor to show up for the proof to go through? (We certainly cancel units on the right in the picture)

Ah, right. Now I am confused too lol.

Mike Shulman said:

I think all the 1-morphisms in this diagram are identities, and the left and right unitor coincide on identities.

Okay, that's the explanation I sought!

(I've not been feeling well enough to do math for much of the last week, unfortunately. However, today I have the energy to do a little bit!)

I'd like to think about this at least briefly today:

If XXX is a monoid object in the category Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon of monoids, then XXX is a commutative monoid object in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon.

Let us assume that XXX is a monoid object in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon. To start out with, I want to understand why this would mean we have an induced commutative multiplication on the elements of XXX.

Since XXX is an object of Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon, it is a monoid and so we have for XXX some corresponding unit element 1∘1_\circ1∘​ and some multiplication rule ∘\circ∘. But since XXX is also a monoid object in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon, we must have some morphism ⊗:X×X→X\otimes:X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X and some morphism e:1→Xe:1 \to Xe:1→X where 111 is the terminal monoid (which has just the identity element, ∗*∗). Here, X×XX \times XX×X has the multiplication induced by applying ∘\circ∘ componentwise.

Intuitively, since XXX is a monoid object, I suspect that ⊗:X×X→X\otimes: X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X must provide an associative operation on XXX that is unital with respect to 1⊗=e(∗)1_{\otimes} = e(*)1⊗​=e(∗). Then, since ⊗:X×X→X\otimes:X \times X \to X⊗:X×X→X is also a morphism of monoids where X×XX \times XX×X and XXX have multiplications provided by ∘\circ∘, by the discussion above I suspect ⊗\otimes⊗ and ∘\circ∘ must satisfy the interchange law. Assuming all this is true, we could then conclude by the Eckmann-Hilton argument that ∘\circ∘ and ⊗\otimes⊗ are equal and commutative. So, we have a commutative multiplication on XXX.

I may work out the details at some point, but I'll stop here for today.

David Egolf said:

Let us assume that XXX is a monoid object in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon. (....) ⊗\otimes⊗ and ∘\circ∘ must satisfy the interchange law. Assuming all this is true, we could then conclude by the Eckmann-Hilton argument that ∘\circ∘ and ⊗\otimes⊗ are equal and commutative. So, we have a commutative multiplication on XXX.

Nice. Hope you feel better soon.

When you do work out the details, if you have the energy, I have two questions

  1. When you say X×XX\times XX×X has the multiplication component-wise, I assume you're talking about the product monoid, not ⊗\otimes⊗. If that's correct, (how/why) do we know Mon\sf MonMon must have finite products?
  2. I'm curious if/where your argument changes if the category containing the monoid object is, say, Ab\sf AbAb, the category of abelian groups, instead? Like, would you (not) end up with a commutative group?

Thanks for your comments, @Eric M Downes ! I think your questions will be interesting and helpful for me to think about.

Regarding question (1): The multiplication on X×XX \times XX×X I mentioned above works as follows. If we have elements (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) and (a′,b′)(a',b')(a′,b′) in XXX, and we use ⋅\cdot⋅ to denote the multiplication on X×XX \times XX×X, then (a,b)⋅(a′,b′)=(a∘a′,b∘b′)(a,b) \cdot (a',b') = (a \circ a', b \circ b')(a,b)⋅(a′,b′)=(a∘a′,b∘b′). Here ∘\circ∘ is the multiplication on the elements of XXX that makes XXX a monoid, an object of Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon.

I believe that X×XX \times XX×X together with ⋅\cdot⋅ is indeed a product of the monoid XXX (which has multiplication ∘\circ∘) with itself in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon.

Note that by Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon I mean the category of "classical" or "elementary" monoids. I'm not working here with a category of monoids internal to some arbitrary monoidal category. (Although I seem to recall that Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon is the same as Mon(Set)\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{Set})Mon(Set), the category of monoids internal to Set\mathsf{Set}Set).

Regarding the question "how/why do we know that Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon must have finite products?", I think I've just assumed that the product monoid we can form from two monoids is in fact the categorical product of those two monoids in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon. But it might be good to prove this!

For clarity, I will start denoting monoids here as pairs of the form (X,∘X)(X, \circ_X)(X,∘X​), where XXX is a set and ∘X:X×X→X\circ_X:X \times X \to X∘X​:X×X→X is a unital associative binary operation on XXX. Given a monoid (A,∘A)(A, \circ_A)(A,∘A​) and a monoid (B,∘B)(B, \circ_B)(B,∘B​), I claim that they have a categorical product given by the monoid (A×B,⋅)(A \times B, \cdot)(A×B,⋅). Here ⋅\cdot⋅ is the "component-wise" multiplication which works like this for any elements (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) and (a′,b′)(a',b')(a′,b′) in A×BA \times BA×B: we have (a,b)⋅(a′,b′)=(a∘a′,b∘b′)(a,b) \cdot (a',b') = (a \circ a',b \circ b')(a,b)⋅(a′,b′)=(a∘a′,b∘b′).

To show that (A×B,⋅)(A \times B, \cdot)(A×B,⋅), together with its projection morphisms πA\pi_AπA​ and πB\pi_BπB​, is indeed a product of (A,∘A)(A, \circ_A)(A,∘A​) and (B,∘B)(B, \circ_B)(B,∘B​), it suffices to show it satisfies the universal property of products. To do this, we need to show that for any monoid (C,∘C)(C, \circ_C)(C,∘C​) with monoid homomorphisms f:(C,∘C)→(C,∘A)f:(C, \circ_C) \to (C, \circ_A)f:(C,∘C​)→(C,∘A​) and g:(C,∘C)→(C,∘B)g:(C, \circ_C) \to (C, \circ_B)g:(C,∘C​)→(C,∘B​), there is then a unique monoid homomorphism (f,g):(C,∘C)→(A×B,⋅)(f,g):(C, \circ_C) \to (A \times B, \cdot)(f,g):(C,∘C​)→(A×B,⋅) that makes this diagram in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon commute:
diagram

Note that πA:(A×B,⋅)→(A,∘A)\pi_A:(A \times B, \cdot) \to (A, \circ_A)πA​:(A×B,⋅)→(A,∘A​) acts by πA(a,b)=a\pi_A(a,b) = aπA​(a,b)=a, and similarly πB(a,b)=b\pi_B(a,b) = bπB​(a,b)=b for all (a,b)∈A×B(a,b) \in A \times B(a,b)∈A×B.

David Egolf said:

Note that by Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon I mean the category of "classical" or "elementary" monoids. I'm not working here with a category of monoids internal to some arbitrary monoidal category. (Although I seem to recall that Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon is the same as Mon(Set)\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{Set})Mon(Set), the category of monoids internal to Set\mathsf{Set}Set).

Yes, monoids in Set\mathsf{Set}Set are the original monoids, and 95% of mathematicians only know about these. Then there are people who know about monoids in a category C\mathsf{C}C with finite products, often called internal monoids or monoid objects in C\mathsf{C}C. And then there are people who know about the even more general monoids in a monoidal category (C,⊗)(\mathsf{C}, \otimes)(C,⊗), also called internal monoids or monoid objects in (C,⊗)(\mathsf{C}, \otimes)(C,⊗). And of course you want to be one of those people.

David Egolf said:

Regarding the question "how/why do we know that Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon must have finite products?", I think I've just assumed that the product monoid we can form from two monoids is in fact the categorical product of those two monoids in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon. But it might be good to prove this!

It's true, in any event. More generally, if C\mathsf{C}C is any category with finite products, Mon(C)\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{C})Mon(C) is again a category with finite products. But if (C,⊗)(\mathsf{C}, \otimes)(C,⊗) is merely a monoidal category, Mon(C)\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{C})Mon(C) may not monoidal, at least not in any standard way. If (C,⊗)(\mathsf{C}, \otimes)(C,⊗) is a braided monoidal category, Mon(C)\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{C})Mon(C) is monoidal. And if (C,⊗)(\mathsf{C}, \otimes)(C,⊗) is a symmetric monoidal category, then we get another stable situation: Mon(C)\mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{C})Mon(C) is again symmetric monoidal. (I think I said this earlier in this long conversation.)

Just to wrap up the above, if (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) is to make the above diagram commute, we need πA∘(f,g)=f\pi_A \circ (f,g) = fπA​∘(f,g)=f. Thus, for any c∈Cc \in Cc∈C we need to have πA((f,g)(c))=f(c)\pi_A((f,g)(c)) = f(c)πA​((f,g)(c))=f(c). So, the first coordinate of (f,g)(c)(f,g)(c)(f,g)(c) must be f(c)f(c)f(c). Similarly, we must have πB((f,g)(c))=g(c)\pi_B((f,g)(c)) = g(c)πB​((f,g)(c))=g(c), and so the second coordinate of (f,g)(c)(f,g)(c)(f,g)(c) must be g(c)g(c)g(c). We conclude that, if (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) exists, then we must have (f,g)(c)=(f(c),g(c))(f,g)(c) = (f(c),g(c))(f,g)(c)=(f(c),g(c)) for any c∈Cc \in Cc∈C. So if, if (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) exists, it is unique.

It remains to show that this (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) makes our diagram commute. But (πA∘(f,g))(c)=πA((f(c),g(c))=f(c)(\pi_A \circ (f,g))(c) = \pi_A((f(c), g(c)) = f(c)(πA​∘(f,g))(c)=πA​((f(c),g(c))=f(c) and (πB∘(f,g))(c)=πB((f(c),g(c))=g(c)(\pi_B \circ (f,g))(c) = \pi_B((f(c), g(c)) = g(c)(πB​∘(f,g))(c)=πB​((f(c),g(c))=g(c). So (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) does make our diagram commute!

We conclude that (A×B,⋅)(A \times B, \cdot)(A×B,⋅) is a product of (A,∘A)(A, \circ_A)(A,∘A​) and (B,∘B)(B, \circ_B)(B,∘B​) in Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon. So, Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon has at least binary products.
Great! And I guess you can see Mon\mathsf{Mon}Mon also has nullary products, aka a terminal object. So it has finite products.

More generally, I suppose there is some induction procedure to show we have finite products of more than two objects, given that we have binary products.

Or, perhaps much more simply, one could just carry out an argument similar to what I did above, except modifying the argument to form the product of nnn monoids instead of two.

There is an interesting related exercise (which I have not worked through) in "Categories for the Working Mathematician" by Mac Lane:

Prove: if BBB has finite products, so does Mon(B)\mathsf{Mon}(B)Mon(B).

So, our result discussed above is a special case of this exercise, where B=SetB = \mathsf{Set}B=Set.

We can also infer that a category from algebra C\sf CC has finite products (even if they are not cartesian) whenever we know we can speak of C\sf CC-objects, the defining diagrams of which form the "syntactic category" of the [[Lawvere theory]] of C\sf CC. These syntactic categories require products for their expression, at least of an object with itself in this case.

Despite the imposing terminology, you actually already know much of the mathematical content, and for Mon\sf MonMon have illustrated it above in your proof! Yet the existence of a lawvere theory is not trivial -- not all categories related to abstract algebra have products. Can you think of one?

Regarding universal products which are not strictly cartesian in a set-theoretic sense.

Consider the following injective faithful functor Z:Mon→Mon0Z:{\sf Mon}\to{\sf Mon^0}Z:Mon→Mon0 where the latter is the category of "pointed possibly-empty monoids with an adjoined zero", and its morphisms always preserve the zero, but otherwise act as they did before. That is, an external zero (idempotent absorbing element) is adjoined even if one was already present internally and each externally-evident zero is identified in each monoid. I can provide the syntactic category and the initial object etc. if you like, or prove functoriality.

In this category, I want the product to be the smash-product
M0×0N0=(M×N)/∼0M^0\times^0 N^0=(M\times N)/\sim^0M0×0N0=(M×N)/∼0 where ∼0\sim^0∼0 will be the equivalence class:
(m,0)∼(0,n)∼(0,0)∼0 ∀m∈M,n∈N(m,0)\sim(0,n)\sim(0,0)\sim0~\forall m\in M, n\in N(m,0)∼(0,n)∼(0,0)∼0 ∀m∈M,n∈N.

I know, I know that's kind of cheating, like its heart is totally cartesian, but we can agree it is not strictly a cartesian product. Nonetheless, I assert without proof that this product is the universal product in this somewhat artificial but legit category.
So perhaps John, you would call that a "monoidal product"? If so, I think that is better terminology.

Yeah, take a look at the first chapter in MacLane and he shows the diagrams for a monoid object, a group object, and a group-action-object. These are just formalization of the equations that define those algebraic varieties, but externalized so that we only see the "inversion morphism", "identity morphism", "multiplication morphism" etc. Everything else is "hidden" away from prying eyes safely within the object.

So then you can get fancy with them, and say "I am in the category Top\sf TopTop and as I have proven that XXX partakes in all the correct diagrams for a group object, so I assert that XXX is a topological group." and then you would drop the mic. (Or at least you could have dropped the mic if you did this like 60 years ago! It's pretty common now.)

Everything else is "hidden" away from prying eyes safely within the object.

And yet, you can probe such internal algebra objects by targeting them with arrows from other objects. In other words, a group object (for example) means precisely an object GGG whose contravariant representable C(−,G)\mathsf{C}(-, G)C(−,G) is, as a set-valued functor, equipped with natural group structure. GGG may think it is safe from prying eyes, but GGG would reveal itself as a terrible poker player: all objects XXX can tell just by looking at GGG that C(X,G)\mathsf{C}(X, G)C(X,G) carries group structure. :-)

I’d like to recall some definitions here. If CCC is “symmetric monoidal”, this means that CCC is a category plus a binary operation ⋅:Ob(C)×Ob(C)→Ob(C)\cdot : Ob(C) \times Ob(C) \to Ob(C)⋅:Ob(C)×Ob(C)→Ob(C), such that:

(A⋅B)⋅C=A⋅(B⋅C)(A \cdot B) \cdot C = A \cdot (B \cdot C)(A⋅B)⋅C=A⋅(B⋅C)

A⋅B=B⋅AA \cdot B = B \cdot AA⋅B=B⋅A

and there exists E∈Ob(C)E \in Ob(C)E∈Ob(C) s.t. E⋅A=AE \cdot A = AE⋅A=A.

I think that this operation ⋅\cdot⋅ can be thought of as a functor ⋅:C×C→C\cdot : C \times C \to C⋅:C×C→C, but I also think this implies we would have to be working in a category whose objects are categories and which has categorical products. Julius Hamilton said:

I’d like to recall some definitions here. If CCC is “symmetric monoidal”, this means that CCC is a category plus a binary operation ⋅:Ob(C)×Ob(C)→Ob(C)\cdot : Ob(C) \times Ob(C) \to Ob(C)⋅:Ob(C)×Ob(C)→Ob(C), such that:

(A⋅B)⋅C=A⋅(B⋅C)(A \cdot B) \cdot C = A \cdot (B \cdot C)(A⋅B)⋅C=A⋅(B⋅C)

A⋅B=B⋅AA \cdot B = B \cdot AA⋅B=B⋅A

and there exists E∈Ob(C)E \in Ob(C)E∈Ob(C) s.t. E⋅A=AE \cdot A = AE⋅A=A.

That's not the definition of a symmetric monoidal category! It's the definition of a very special case, which I call a "commutative monoidal category". In a general symmetric monoidal category, all these equations are replaced by isomorphisms, which need to obey coherence laws. (See the link.)
Very few symmetric monoidal categories are, or are even equivalent to, commutative monoidal categories.

As you and Eric know, but others here might not, this trick of replacing constants with constant functions lets us turn any Lawvere theory into a new Lawvere theory that has all the same nonempty algebras in the category Set\mathsf{Set}Set, but also one empty algebra.

But what is a little slippery is that it looked like Eric didn't use this trick for both the zero and the identity element, i.e., it looked (to me) like Eric introduced a zero constant, as opposed to a zero constant function. [He said, "with an adjoined zero."] If so, then there's no difference between this whatchamacallit with zero, and a monoid with zero. That's because, if MMM has a zero constant term 0:1→M0: 1 \to M0:1→M, then you get the identity constant term as f∘0:1→Mf \circ 0: 1 \to Mf∘0:1→M where f:M→Mf: M \to Mf:M→M is this constant function, hence you're getting a monoid after all, none of this confusing business.

Okay. Yes, if you replace a bunch of the constants in your Lawvere theory TTT by constant functions, but keep at least one constant in the theory, then you get a new Lawvere theory T′T'T′ whose algebras in Set\mathsf{Set}Set are "the same" as those of TTT, and thus T≅T′T \cong T'T≅T′. So, in some sense there was no point introducing T′T'T′.

(This is a semantic argument, sketched out in a way that could be filled in, but you can also see T≅T′T \cong T'T≅T′ directly by a generalization of the syntactic argument you just gave.)

(And here Todd means ∧\land∧ to be the smash product not "logical and")

So I don't know what to call ×0\times^0×0, I just want it to exist. It has a different unit than the product so not identical by Eckmann-Hilton, thankfully. I'll go with "a monoidal product" for now I guess.

And thanks for the correction on the adjoint conventions.

Well, just to let onlookers know which direction I was about to head in: earlier I said that products in a category of algebras of a Lawvere theory are calculated just as they are in sets, which is to say that the forgetful functor TAlg→SetT\mathsf{Alg} \to \mathsf{Set}TAlg→Set preserves products. And one nice way to see that's true is that this forgetful functor is representable, and representable functors preserve products, by the very definition of categorical product, a conversation that David Egolf will certainly remember. In this case, the representing object, which is the free algebra on one generator, can be presented as {0,1,2,4,8,…}\{0, 1, 2, 4, 8, \ldots\}{0,1,2,4,8,…} (under multiplication).

Now, back here, I'll start with point (2). I don't know if you saw the "slippery point" I mentioned, but there's no need for this tricky unary business, because as soon as you have one constant, then all constants can be reinstated (are terms in the theory), and so you may as well present the theory using the constant terms rather than bother with the tricky unary business. If eee is your unary operation, then the constant 111 can be defined as e(0)e(0)e(0).

So according to my current understanding of your category, it really is just monoids with a zero element.

I also want to say, regarding point (1), that the initial object is {0,1}\{0, 1\}{0,1}, not {0}\{0\}{0}.

Yes, its supposed to be monoids with a zero element, while capturing the ability to take products that preserve the original monoids. It's really quite uninteresting by itself, and I'm sorry for spending so much time on it; I hope some of the above has been useful to others, or if not that you all had some popcorn handy.

Re (1) -- I suppose you are reminding me that monoid homomorphisms preserve 1, so even if I am asking them to also preserve 0, and one is unary, there cannot be a monoid homomorphism that does both from { 0 }\set0{0}. Thank you.

Todd Trimble said:

Now, back here, I'll start with point (2). I don't know if you saw the "slippery point" I mentioned, but there's no need for this tricky unary business, because as soon as you have one constant, then all constants can be reinstated (are terms in the theory), and so you may as well present the theory using the constant terms rather than bother with the tricky unary business. If eee is your unary operation, then the constant 111 can be defined as e(0)e(0)e(0).

So to present the Lawvere theory, you are recommending I just bite the bullet and define η,ζ:1→M\eta,\zeta:1\to Mη,ζ:1→M as my constants, as there is nothing one can do with unary constants that cannot also be done with nullary constants; the approaches are entirely equivalent save only that one can have empty objects in a unary-constants-only theory.

Not a problem! I had forgotten this stuff about eliminating constant terms, so it was actually a little bit fun thinking things through.

The other option you have is to introduce an unary operation for zero as well, and then the empty structure can get readmitted to your category, if you like. But the slogan here is that: once you have one constant term, you have them all. It's an all-or-nothing proposition. :-)

Much of the conversation here is going over my head! I think if I were aiming to gain more understanding from what's been posted above, it would probably help if I knew a bit more about "Lawvere theories". I may return to this thread at some point to try and learn more in that direction...

But for now I feel that I've gained a somewhat better understanding of the Eckmann-Hilton argument and some related things. (Although there is still more to learn in that direction, too!) For that reason, I am going to focus my efforts on a different thread for a while.

Thanks again to everyone for their comments here!
